title: Are Iranian people considered 'white' in the US? - Quora

response.answer_text: Officially; as in, by the US government (or if you’re living here and applying for jobs online, or something like that — since those forms will typically be within federal guidelines), then yes Iranians are taken by the government here as ‘white/Caucasian’. https://www.census.gov/prod/cen2010/briefs/c2010br-05.pdf See page 2 on the above link (it’s a .pdf). It says: “DEFINITION OF WHITE USED IN THE 2010 CENSUS According to OMB, ‘White’ refers to a person having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa. The White racial category includes people who marked the ‘White’ checkbox. It also includes respondents who reported entries such as Caucasian or White; European entries, such as Irish, German, and Polish; Middle Eastern entries, such as Arab, Lebanese, and Palestinian; and North African entries, such as Algerian, Moroccan, and Egyptian.” Socially; likely not as much taken as white, IMO. But, I guess some of that may be up to the individual Iranian’s self-identification and/or his or her physical appearance really as well. If the person is an Iranian who looks more like they wouldn’t be out of place in southern Italy or Greece, then they might be perceived as just another type of American of southern Euro descent (of which we have plenty here). If they are of a ‘browner’ skin tone, noticeably non-European descent by appearance, with a look closer to neighboring South Asians like Indians or Pakistanis, then no they won’t be likely socially considered as white. Many average people here might think they’re Arabs (wrongly), “Middle Easterners” (vague), “Muslims” (which they probably are, but which is neither a race nor an ethnic group), or Indians, Pakistanis, etc.

White is often a default category, thought of as American without any minority labeling. (The point of “whiteness studies” is recognizing it does have characteristics and history.) With some kids assuming that Hispanic necessarily means not white, I bet you would find some kids today who would answer “Iranians are Muslim not white”. Also there are some who assume “Arab” is a racial category meaning Middle Eastern, rather than defined by language and country. To the US Census, Middle East and North Africa have been presumed white since the first census in 1790. The Census category started as a default, and Mexicans were also presumed white from the first 1850 census after annexation through 1920, then a separate category was introduced in 1930, then withdrawn in 1940. Today only self-identification is used. People trying to be polite would probably avoid telling an Iranian he is white or is not white, and likely not be sure themselves.

It depends on the circumstance and how you define “white”. My father, who is from Shiraz, Iran, was often mistaken for being Eastern European (such as Slavic) or even German by Americans because he has light-colored skin compared to some other Iranians. When taking a census a test, Iranians are often categorized as “white” and historically were considered “caucasian”, so demographically they are labeled as so. Iran, however, is a vastly diverse nation with multiple ethnic groups. An Arab-Iranian from the desert region of Khuzestan may not appear “white” by Western standards, whereas a Persian-Iranian from Shiraz or Tehran could have blue eyes and light brown hair and appear “white” like my father. Social context is important. The concept of “whiteness” sometimes changes for Iranians when Americans here their language (Farsi), observe their cultural practices, or simply recognize they are non-European. I know many Iranian-Americans (family members I grew up with) who were rejected from the socially-constructed group of “whiteness” after the hostage crisis in 1979 and especially during the War on Terror. So history certainly plays an important part in whether Iranians are labeled as “white” or not.

There isn’t a single answer. The US Census defines white as people with roots in Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. The category is not completely consistent, because Asians are generally considered minority, and the Middle East part not in North Africa is obviously Asian. So, it’s a matter of what individual people think. In my experience, people from Iran and the Middle East are considered “white.” Some Americans have no idea of what continent Iran is on. The number of Iranian-Americans is maybe 400,000, too small to make much of an impact. A black friend of mine, for example, tosses Africa, Asia and Europe together as “over there someplace.” He’s not a stupid man, he’s just not educated and has no real reason to care.

EDIT: When I originally answered, the question was “Are Iranians considered white?”. The question has since been merged with another question, then unmerged, and rewritten as above. I would not (and did not) answer a “Why” question with “Yes”. Please consider that the question was rewritten when you read my answer. Incidentally, race is self-reported in the census - the people filling out the forms considered themselves to be white. The tabulation will also tell you about Afghans, and people from (probably) every other country. Just scroll to the appropriate lines. END EDIT Yes. In this tabulation, scroll down to lines 538–542 for the people from Iran. Those who have come to the USA are overwhelmingly classified as “White”. For an explanation of the tabulation, see this quora answer (I used the same tabulation there).

First, we must assert that race is a biological fiction. There is more intra race genetic variation than inter race genetic variation, so the the distinctions we make visually using a very few phenotypical markers has almost nothing to do with the actual genetic makeup of the individual. To the vast majority of people in the US, you are either “white” or something else. So going by appearances alone, Pakistanis or South Asian Indians (particularly the darker hued individuals), for example, mostly fall into the “non-white” category, regardless of what the Census or US Immigration classify them as. So would most Iranians if they had a darker complexion, copious body hair, and other “non-white” visual markers. Light skinned, more “European” looking Iranians could probably “pass” for white. Since being “white” is a big advantage in the US, most people who can pass for white do so.

As far as I know, in USA, anyone who doesn’t look like Western/Northern European is considered not looking white enough. This is because some Southern Europeans and Middle Easterners are often mistaken as Latinos. There’s a video on YouTube about “black and white” prisoners and the comment section is filled with Americans stating that the white ones look Hispanic/Latin. The European users then replied that those white prisoners look white enough and can pass as Southern Europeans. Also, I’ve heard reports of Southern Europeans being mistaken as Latinos when they’re in USA. It seems that thick eye brows, hooked-down nose, olive skin tone, and round eyes are considered not white enough by some Americans.

Iranians are considered white when it comes to filling government applications. US government officially recognizes Iranians and people of the ME white. However,socially and culturally they are not. “White” race is a small and privileged club in the US. It is typically reserved for people of Western European and of Anglo decent. It took many decades for Europeans of Mediterranean origin to be considered white. For example for many decades Italians where not considered white. It is reasonable to assume it will take at least that long for anyone of ME origin to be considered White, if ever. There are definite distinctions between White race in general and the “White” club.

First of all I can’t say Iran is majority Fars\Persian. Iran is definitely majority Persian - speaking. But ethnically the country does not have an ethnic majority. There are too many mixed people in Iran. The answer to your question is YES. Iranians as other Middle Easterners are considere White\Caucasian in the United States. As Arab people, Central Asians, Pakistanis and Afghans.  The percentage of ancestry of White Americans among the population.

The definition of ‘white’ in the US varies from time to time, and possibly with the political climate. Not too long ago, Italians were considered non-white. Race and ethnicity are largely misunderstood in this country. Take the example of a South American woman married to a Southern European man. She is direct descendent of Northern Portuguese and Spaniards and has a light skin tone. He was borne in Southern Italy and has very dark skin. Here in the US, he is a white caucasian, but she is not. So are Iranian considered ‘white’ in the US? I think it will depend on to whom and when you are asking.

I’m a Persian American (maiden name Ansari) and I have been told by white people that I’m white, African Americans that I’m black, and Hispanics that I’m brown. lol. It’s a crapshoot when trying to define the middle eastern “race” and people will hold their own opinions on our color/race. According to job applications I am white. But I always chose the “two or more races” category. I can’t say I truly identify with any race. Despite my pale skin, I have very ethnic Persian facial features.

If going by the US Census definition of “white”which means anyone originating from Europe, Middle East and North Africa then YES they are “white” since MENA people are included. However in everyday life in the US, they aren’t being treated as one. That is totally unfair and has to change. Although I understand the underlying reason why MENA people are currently included in the white category but the consequence is that they are like invisible and their voices aren’t being heard of since they are officially part of the default majority group. In effect they are “white” only on census forms.

No, but on the Census they might be grouped as Caucasians for practical purposes, however, this is changing in 2020 I believe. There is a proposition of having a Middle-Eastern & Northern African box or category. They are generally seen as Middle-Easterners and may arouse suspicion if they act too agitated at airports. I also don’t consider them Whites, they are usually very black-haired, black-eyed, hooked-nose, hairy, just have a different look about them.

According to the census, yes. According to society, no. Same goes for the majority from North Africa and West Asia (I’m going to include Armenians, Azeris, and Afghans here as they also fall into the “some of us look white, some of us do not” category). White Americans and Canadians of European descent do not consider us to be white, even if we physically look white. That’s my experience living here. I’m literally whiter than my friends of European descent and I’m still considered to be a non-white minority because I’m Iranian.

There are specific ethnicities that have people in two or more colors. Take a Dominican guy from the Dominican Republic for example. They could be white, black, or brown. Take a guy from Pakistan. A guy from Khyber will look more European. But in Punjab, Sindh and else were people will be dark brown or light brown. Take a guy from Mexico. I've seen European looking Mexicans and Mexicans that are just brown. Or even pale. It really depends on what part of the country you’re from. So I guess yeah, you can call somebody based on what color they are even though they may not be known to everyone that way commonly. And I don't mean to say they're mixed, they're by DNA what they are.

I have know some Iranian people and they are great people. I have never thought of anybody being “not -white” because it never entered my mind at all. The reason blacks once stuck out in my mind is because they always made skin color an issue. I see people as potential friends and just like in high school my friend Mohamed were best of buddy's. I thought he was really cool and never thought if he was white or not. We got to stop this identify war that liberals seem to push.

if Abbas Naderi considers Jewish people, Spanish people or the British to be nonwhite, he is not using the definitions used by the federal government in collecting Census and educational data. These people may not be Aryan, but they are definitely considered white for purposes of racial classification.

The USA census calls out all peoples from the Middle East and Noth Africa as “white” so by this term they are white. However, if you go by the American stereotype of middle America which is the Nordic look as the main stereotype. Someone, with brown skin may not be considered “white”. I am sorry to say that this is factual.
This is a Map of indigenous peoples in the world who carry the genes for light skin:  So yes, Iranians have light skin and resemble Southern Europeans.

If you ask most Americans what races exist, they will say three: White, Black and Asian. Then ask them about Iranians. At that point, the answer is most likely to be White. Americans can become easily befuddled on the topic of race since you have identities that are associated with race and ethnicity and not all Americans know the difference.

Well if it makes any since i live in new york and am around alot of arabs every day i speak english very well i know farsi as a second language when i hear arabs speak arabic i dont think they know i understand alot of what they are saying im Iranian and everytime i fill out a app for a job i just choose Caucasian anyways becuase it list peoples from Europe north africa and the middle east im Iranian im white  Aryan :)
By the government yes, but the average person the street? It depends on what you look like. https://www.census.gov/mso/www/training/pdf/race-ethnicity-onepager.pdf
For census and various governmental purposes, yes. Socially, not so much. When Americans hear “Muslim”, they usually assume that the person so described is “non-white”.
They are defined as white legally, but whether they are treated as white really depends. Most Azeris are assumed to be white but often Persians are mistaken as Hispanics.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Richard Joseph Strachan

response.answer_text: From time to time it is mentioned in TV that even Italians are not real white.
not really
